awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: The Financialization of Industrial Waste Recycling
awd_abstract_narration:
Considerable waste is generated in industrial settings, and efforts are frequently made to recycle waste more efficiently and profitably. The commoditization of waste among transnational institutions has broad economic, environmental, and health implications for communities that engage in the trade of waste. This study focuses in particular on the recycling of scrap metal from the shipbuilding industry, which employs large numbers of workers in domestic and international contexts. At multiple sites, the researchers use a complement of ethnographic methods to examine how working conditions, social organization, and ecological factors are impacted by fluctuations in the transnational flows of waste and its financialization. Relevant findings are shared with diverse stakeholders to improve local and global recycling infastructures in ways that enhance the working conditions of laborers in the industry while minimizing environmental impacts.

This doctoral dissertation project examines the social and ecological consequences of changes in the commoditization of scrap metal waste. The researchers employ participant observation among financial professionals working in international scrap-metal markets. Similar ethnographic methods are used among workers at a ship-breaking yard. In addition to participation observation, semi-structured interviews will be conducted with a sample of key informants at both sites. Surveys and archival research on changes in the policies and economics of the scrap-metal provide complementary data that contextualize the ethnographic research. The findings of this research contribute to debates in economic anthropology, science and technology studies, and scholarship on the anthropology of finance, work, and waste. The project also contributes to the education of a graduate student in the social sciences.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The global cartography of steel production went through a colossal transformation in the 1980s. Thatcher-era privatization policies nearly brought an end to steel production in South Wales, West-Central Scotland, and England's West Midlands. US Steel closures made hundreds of thousands of workers redundant and led to drastic population displacement in Western Pennsylvania and the Midwest. De-industrialization in the Global North triggered the emergence of steel towns in the developing Global South where imported ferrous scrap is transformed into steel products by using electric-arc-furnaces (EAF). More recently, transnationally-traded ferrous scrap entered into financial markets where scrap contracts are now traded as financial derivatives. This research examined the rising prominence of scrap metal recycling in global steel production and analyzed the impacts of the financialization of imported ferrous scrap on industrial employees, ecologies of industrial recycling, and the residential communities who live near the scrap recycling facilities.

This multi-sited project focused on the case of Turkiye, the world's biggest ferrous scrap importer, and the global centers of metals trade and finance. Over the 22-month research period, we conducted ethnographic fieldwork at the EAF-based steel plants, industrial ports which facilitate transnational steel scrap imports and exports, and the global financial centers of metals exchange. Semi-structured interviews were conducted with steelworkers, dockworkers, seafarers, surveyors, metallurgical engineers, and professionals in the field of scrap finance. Finally, we conducted archival research about the emergence of transnational scrap routes as well as the financial and legal proceedings regarding the overseas scrap trade. We found that decoupling financialization from industrial processes and the clear-cut separation between the 'post-industrial' centers of global finance and contemporary industrial geographies lead to ecological and occupational problems for the steel sector. For instance, we observed that the scrap imported from the significantly deindustrialized countries of the Global North contain high levels of copper and lead concentration, both unwanted elements in steel production while lead also poses risks toward ecologies of industrial recycling and workers' health. We suggest the North American and European governments to incentivize industrial employment opportunities through which copper and lead can be separated from ferrous scrap safely before this commodity's use in domestic steel plants or its export to the steel factories overseas.

Based on our findings, we also recommend the governments and the global steel sector to work together in developing occupational clinical psychology programs which can address the emotional and behavioral problems that the industrial employees are experiencing due to working at high-risk and high-stimulation environments. Our informants reported a sharp divide between the spatial and material layout of their workplaces from the residential and recreational areas where they spend the rest of their time. This leads to senses of separation and estrangement from their families and social circles, given the latter groups' unfamiliarity with the dangerous and explosive workplace atmosphere in which the workers and engineers spend a significant portion of their day. Several informants expressed the need to address these issues with clinical psychologists who are familiar with the spatial and material layout of their working conditions. Developing occupational clinical psychology programs and insurance benefits to meet this demand would contribute to industrial workers' and engineers' well-being and overall workplace safety.
